questions.question: Match the following: i. Heroin 1. Ganja ii. MDMA 2. Acid iii. Joint 3. Brown sugar iv. LSD 4. Amphetamine
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) i -3, ii-4, iii-1, iv-2 Explanation: Drugs Local names Cocaine Coke, snow, Cadillac, white lady , crack (cocaine + baking soda + water) MDMA Molly, love drug, ecstasy, Amphetamine Heroin Smack, brown sugar , Black tar, speedball(mixed with cocaine) Cannabis Marijuana, pot, grass, joint , ganja , dope, weed, hash, Mary Jane, M.J LSD Acid , Alice, Angel in the Sky, Lucy Ketamine K, Special K, Kit-Kat, K Hole Methamphetamine Ice, Glass, Crystal meth, Meth, Speed Reference: Drug Slang Code Words | Drug enforcement agency Gautam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, Page 566

questions.question: Hooch tragedy is related to:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Methanol Explanation A "hooch tragedy" refers to incidents of poisoning caused by the consumption of illicit or adulterated alcohol. Methanol, a toxic alcohol, is often found in illegally brewed liquor as a contaminant. Ingesting methanol leads to metabolic acidosis, blindness, and potentially fatal outcomes due to its toxic metabolites, formaldehyde and formic acid. Phosphorus (Option A): Phosphorus poisoning typically occurs due to ingestion of rodenticides or fireworks, causing severe gastrointestinal and hepatic damage. It is not related to hooch tragedies. Mercury (Option B): Mercury poisoning occurs due to exposure to mercury compounds, causing neurological and renal toxicity. It is unrelated to alcohol adulteration. Ethanol (Option C): Ethanol is the active ingredient in alcoholic beverages and is generally not the cause of toxicity in hooch tragedies. The issue "hooch tragedy" occurred when ethanol was adulterated with methanol. Reference: pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3665074/

questions.question: A male patient presented with a history of consuming an unknown substance. He exhibited increased sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, and bradycardia. What is management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Atropine Explanation The symptoms described—sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, and bradycardia—are consistent with cholinergic toxicity, commonly caused by organophosphate or carbamate poisoning. Atropine is the first-line treatment for cholinergic toxicity. It is a muscarinic receptor antagonist that counteracts the effects of excessive acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, reducing secretions, bradycardia, and other parasympathetic symptoms. Symptoms Muscarinic: Lethargy, Salivation, Diarrhea, Lacrimation, Urination, Miosis, Muscle weakness, Bronchorrhea, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Emesis (Mnemonic: DUMBBELLS) Nicotinic: Muscle weakness, Fasciculation, Areflexia, Muscle paralysis CNS: Headache, Tremor, Confusion, Slurred speech, Coma, Convulsion Laboratory Diagnosis RBC/True Cholinesterase (specific) Plasma/Pseudocholinesterase (Most common) Falls rapidly with organophosphorus poisoning Inexpensive, sensitive) Atropine test : If 2 mg of Atropine relieves symptoms, it confirms OP poisoning P-nitro phenol test for confirmation. Management Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing-Circulation) Decontamination Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4 Activated charcoal Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization) Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms removes phosphate group reduces atropine requirement Cause of Death Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP) Calcium gluconate (Option B): Used primarily for hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, or calcium channel blocker toxicity. It does not address cholinergic symptoms. Pralidoxime (Option C): Pralidoxime (2-PAM) reactivates acetylcholinesterase inhibited by organophosphates. It is used alongside atropine but is not the initial management step . Atropine is given first to stabilize the patient. Obidoxime (Option D): Similar to pralidoxime, obidoxime is an oxime used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase. However, it is not the primary treatment for immediate symptom control. Learning Objective: Antidotes and their mechanisms Poisoning Type Antidote Mechanism Arsenic BAL (Dimercaprol) IM, chelates arsenic for excretion. Succimer (DMSA) Oral chelation. DMPS IV, transitioned to oral chelation. Copper Potassium Ferrocyanide Forms insoluble copper complexes, reducing absorption. Penicillamine Chelates copper. Cyanide Sodium Nitrite Forms methemoglobin to bind cyanide. Sodium Thiosulfate Converts cyanide to thiocyanate for renal excretion. Hydroxocobalamin Binds cyanide, forming cyanocobalamin. Dicobalt Edetate, Methylene Blue Alternative antidotes. Ethylene Glycol Ethanol/Fomepizole Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase to prevent toxic metabolites. Iron Desferrioxamine Chelates iron for excretion. Magnesium Hydroxide/Sodium Bicarbonate Note: BAL should not be used in iron, cadmium, or selenium poisoning due to formation of toxic complexes. Precipitate iron, reducing absorption. Lead Sodium/Magnesium Sulfate Forms insoluble lead sulfate. Calcium Chloride/Gluconate Promotes bone deposition of lead. CaNa2EDTA + BAL Chelation therapy for lead elimination. Mercury Sodium Formaldehyde Sulfoxylate

questions.question: Which of the following are seen in patients with chronic arsenic poisoning? 1. Raindrop pigmentation 2. Peripheral neuritis 3. Mees line 4. Luminous vomit
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1, 2, 3 are correct Explanation Chronic arsenic poisoning commonly presents with raindrop pigmentation, peripheral neuritis, and Mees lines, making Option A the correct answer. Clinical manifestations of Arsenic Poisoning: Acute Arsenic Poisoning Chronic Arsenic Poisoning Dermal Hair loss Mees lines (Aldrich-Mees line or Reynold’s line): Transverse bands of opacity in nails. Melanosis (neck, eyelids, nipples) Bowen’s disease Facial oedema Hyperkeratosis Black foot disease (Peripheral gangrene) Hyperpigmentation (raindrop pattern) Skin cancer (commonly squamous cell carcinoma). Ocular Conjunctivitis Lacrimation Dimension of Vision Gastrointestinal Abdominal pain Metallic taste Garlicky odour Dysphagia Vomiting Diarrhoea (bloody or rice water) Anorexia Nausea Vomiting Diarrhea Weight loss Airway Upper airway irritation Nasal septum perforation Laryngitis Bronchitis Liver Fatty degeneration Hepatomegaly Jaundice Cirrhosis Kidney Oliguria Uraemia Nephritic changes Neurological Hyperpyrexia Convulsions Coma Encephalopathy Polyneuritis (glove & stocking type) Tremor Ataxia Limb tenderness Difficulty in walking Haematological – Anaemia Leucopenia Thrombocytopenia Basophilic stippling (Rare in arsenic poisoning and common in lead poisoning) Karyorrhexis Pancytopenia Cardiac Tachycardia Hypotension Cardiac arrhythmias Hypertension Myocarditis Luminous vomit: This is not associated with chronic arsenic poisoning but can occur in acute poisoning due to phosphorus ingestion. Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 408-410. Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 490, 491. Modern Medical Toxicology, by VV Pillai, 4th Edition, Page 79-82.

questions.question: Identify the given plant based on its features
questions.explanation: and toxic properties. Argemone Mexicana: Commonly known as prickly poppy. The plant is characterized by its yellow flowers, prickly leaves, and a milky sap. It is toxic due to alkaloids such as sanguinarine and dihydrosanguinarine, which can cause health issues like epidemic dropsy. Argemone Mexicana (Prickly Poppy) Toxic Parts Entire plant; seeds resemble mustard seeds but are darker with minute projections. Toxic Oil Argemone oil (katkar oil) causes epidemic dropsy. Active Principles Plant Alkaloids: Berberine, Protopine. Oil Alkaloids: Sanguinarine, Dihydrosanguinarine. (Cause abnormal blood vessel permeability.) General Symptoms Gradual onset with appetite loss, diarrhea, leg edema, and generalized anasarca. System-Specific Signs Heart : Myocardial damage, heart dilatation. CVS: Hypotension, breathlessness, feeble pulse. Hepatic : Enlarged , tender liver. PNS : Tingling, hyperesthesia, calf muscle tenderness, reduced or absent jerks. Ocular : Dim vision due to increased intraocular pressure. Skin : Bluish mottling from peripheral vessel dilation. Fatal Outcome Severe heart damage. Treatment Balanced diet, decontamination, cessation of oil consumption, diuretics, corticosteroids, and supportive care. Medico-Legal Aspects Argemone oil is commonly used to adulterate mustard or other edible oils. Datura Alba (Option A): Known as white datura , it has white trumpet-shaped flowers and is associated with anticholinergic toxicity. Nerium Odorum (Option C) : Known as oleander , it has pink or white flowers and contains cardiac glycosides causing poisoning. Papaver Somniferum (Option D): Commonly known as the opium poppy, it produces latex rich in alkaloids like morphine and codeine.

questions.question: What is the treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning?
questions.explanation: and facilitates its excretion. Management of Arsenic Poisoning Supportive treatment Gastric lavage, airway, breathing, and circulation management (intravenous fluids, cardiac monitoring, etc.). Medical treatment Freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide (chemical antidote) Chelating agents BAL (Dimercaprol) DMSA (Dimercapto succinic acid) or DMPS (Dimercapto propane sulfonic acid) Penicillamine Other measures Purgatives like Castor oil or Magnesium sulfate (remove unabsorbed poison from the intestine). Glucose-saline with sodium bicarbonate. Hemodialysis or exchange transfusion. Ipecac (Option A): Previously used to induce vomiting but is no longer recommended due to the risk of aspiration and limited efficacy. Penicillamine (Option B): Another chelating agent, primarily used for copper poisoning (e.g., Wilson’s disease). Less effective than dimercaprol in arsenic toxicity. Activated charcoal (Option C): Used for gastrointestinal decontamination in various poisonings. Not effective in chelating or removing absorbed arsenic. Reference: Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 408-410. Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 490, 491. Modern Medical Toxicology, by VV Pillai, 4th Edition, Page 79-82.

questions.question: Which of these is not a cardiac poison?
questions.explanation: scopolamine). While it affects the autonomic nervous system (causing tachycardia, dry mouth, and dilated pupils), it is not classified as a direct cardiac poison. Some common cardiac poisons include: Aconite (Aconitum napellus, Aconitum ferox) Nicotine (Nicotiana tabacum) Digitalis (Digitalis purpurea) Oleander (Cerbera thevetia, Cerbera odorum) Quinine. Aconite (Option A): Aconite is cardiac poison derived from the Aconitum plant . It causes arrhythmias, hypotension, and cardiac arrest by altering sodium channel function. Cerbera thevetia (Option B): Commonly known as the "Yellow Oleander," it contains cardiac glycosides that interfere with the sodium-potassium ATPase pump . Nicotiana tabacum (Option C): Tobacco contains nicotine , which can act on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and cause tachycardia or bradycardia depending on the dose. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology by Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 576- 580

questions.question: Gastric lavage, commonly known as stomach pumping or gastric irrigation, is a procedure performed to remove the contents of the stomach. It has been widely used since the early 19th century as a standard method to eliminate toxins from the stomach. This procedure is typically employed for individuals who have consumed poison or overdosed on substances like ethanol. Additionally, it may be performed prior to surgery to empty the digestive tract. In which of the following situations is gastric lavage not recommended?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hydrocarbons Explanation: Gastric Lavage in Poisoning Management Gastric lavage is a procedure to remove ingested poison by introducing and withdrawing fluids through an orogastric tube. Its effectiveness depends on timing, proper technique, and patient-specific considerations. Timing and Effectiveness Most effective within 1 hour of ingestion Can be beneficial up to 4-6 hours in select cases Beyond 6 hours , poison likely passes into the intestines, reducing lavage efficacy Procedure Steps Step Details Patient Positioning Trendelenburg: Head down to prevent aspiration Left lateral decubitus: Reduces chance of poison entering the duodenum Tube Placement Confirmation Inject air and listen for gastric bubbling sounds Watch for coughing or bubbles (indicates misplacement in trachea) Fluid Administration Fluid is administered and aspirated using a syringe attached to the tube Fluid Selection Tap water for most cases Normal saline for infants Specific solutions (e.g., potassium permanganate) may be used for certain poisons Residual Fluid Leave a small amount of fluid to neutralize remaining poison Contraindications Corrosive Poisoning : Avoid except for carbolic acid (phenol) to prevent perforation Convulsant Poisons : Risk of triggering seizures (e.g., strychnine) Comatose Patients : High aspiration risk Volatile Poisons/ Hydrocarbons : May cause aspiration pneumonitis Risk of Hemorrhage/ Perforation : Avoid if esophageal varices or recent surgery present Additional Contraindications to Emetics Severe heart or lung diseases Advanced pregnancy CNS depression or seizures Complications Complication Details Aspiration Occurs in ~10% of cases. Risk of lung injury Esophageal/Gastric Perforation Can be life-threatening Tube Misplacement Misplaced into trachea, causing complications Bleeding Can occur with improper technique or pathology Alternatives to Gastric Lavage Alternative Description Emetics Induce vomiting in conscious patients Dilution Large water intake to dilute corrosive substances Endoscopic/Surgical Removal Used for toxic foreign bodies or drug packets Incorrect Options: Organophosphate poisoning (Option A): Gastric lavage is recommended for organophosphate poisoning (e.g., insecticides) because it can effectively remove the poison from the stomach if performed early, particularly within 1 hour of ingestion. The risks of aspiration or complications are considered manageable in this case with proper techniques. Ethanol poisoning (Option C): Gastric lavage is recommended in cases of ethanol poisoning if it is performed within 1 hour of ingestion. Ethanol is rapidly absorbed, so the procedure is most effective if performed early. Gastric lavage may help prevent further absorption of the alcohol and reduce toxicity. PCM (Paracetamol/Acetaminophen) toxicity (Option D): In PCM

questions.question: In case of corrosive acid ingestion, stomach is opened along the?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Greater curvature In forensic autopsies, the stomach is usually opened along the greater curvature to minimize disruption of stomach anatomy and allows the pathologist to collect and examine the stomach contents effectively, which is critical in cases of suspected poisoning. Procedure for Stomach Dissection: Two ligatures are applied at the cardiac end of the esophagus and two ligatures are below the pyloric end of the stomach. The stomach is removed by cutting between the double ligatures at both ends. The stomach is then opened along the greater curvature . The mucous membrane is examined for the presence of any stains, congestion, hemorrhage, desquamation, ulceration, sloughing, or perforation. The contents of the stomach are noted with respect to quantity, nature of material/food, state of digestion, color, and smell. Reference: Gautam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, pages 104-110

questions.question: Inhaling the cloth soaked in drug is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Huffing Huffing involves inhaling the vapors of an inhalant, typically from a cloth or rag soaked in volatile solvents. It is a method where the substance is directly inhaled through the mouth, and a cloth soaked in the drug is commonly used for this method. Inhalants are substances that produce intoxicating vapors when inhaled, often used by young adolescents. They can cause severe health issues, including cardiac arrest, suffocation, and long-term damage to the brain, heart, kidneys, and liver. Types of Inhalants: Volatile Solvents : Liquids that vaporize at room temperature, found in household and business products like paint thinners, dry-cleaning fluids, gasoline, glues, and felt-tip markers. Aerosols : Products that release vapors when sprayed, such as spray paints, deodorant sprays, hair sprays, and cooking oil sprays. Gases : Gases like nitrous oxide (laughing gas), chloroform, ether, and halothane, used in medical procedures. Also includes gases found in butane lighters, propane tanks, and refrigerants. Nitrites : Sold in small bottles called “poppers,” these primarily dilate blood vessels and relax muscles, acting differently from other inhalants that affect the central nervous system. Bagging (Option A) : This involves inhaling vapors from a substance stored in a plastic bag. It is a common method of inhaling gases or solvents but does not specifically refer to inhaling a cloth soaked in a drug. Spraying (Option B) : This refers to inhaling vapors directly from an aerosol or spray can, such as spray paints or deodorant sprays. It is a method of inhaling aerosol inhalants, but it does not apply to inhaling from a cloth soaked in a drug. Sniffing (Option D) : This involves inhaling vapors directly from a container or surface, such as sniffing glue or other substances. However, it does not specifically refer to inhaling from a cloth soaked in a drug. Reference: Inhalant abuse - PMC Inhalants | National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA)

questions.question: A 72-year-old farmer was presented in the hospital with pinpoint pupil & increased secretions. The diagnosis is
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Organophosphorus poisoning The symptoms of pinpoint pupils (miosis) and increased secretions (such as salivation, lacrimation, and bronchorrhea) are highly suggestive of organophosphorus poisoning . Organophosphates inhibit cholinesterase enzymes, leading to the accumulation of acetylcholine at muscarinic and nicotinic receptors. Symptoms Muscarinic: Lethargy, Salivation, Diarrhea, Lacrimation, Urination, Miosis, Muscle weakness, Bronchorrhea, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Emesis (Mnemonic: DUMBBELLS) Nicotinic: Muscle weakness, Fasciculation, Areflexia, Muscle paralysis CNS: Headache, Tremor, Confusion, Slurred speech, Coma, Convulsion Laboratory Diagnosis RBC/True Cholinesterase (specific) Plasma/Pseudocholinesterase (Most common) Falls rapidly with organophosphorus poisoning Inexpensive, sensitive) Atropine test : If 2 mg of Atropine relieves symptoms, it confirms OP poisoning P-nitro phenol test for confirmation. Management Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing-Circulation) Decontamination Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4 Activated charcoal Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization) Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms removes phosphate group reduces atropine requirement Cause of Death Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP) Alcohol poisoning (Option A) : Alcohol typically causes CNS depression, but does not cause pinpoint pupils or excessive secretions Opioid poisoning (Option B) : Opioids cause miosis (pinpoint pupils) but do not cause excessive secretions or the broad range of symptoms seen in organophosphorus poisoning.\ Datura poisoning (Option D) : Datura causes mydriasis (dilated pupils) and other anticholinergic symptoms like dry mouth, blurred vision, and tachycardia, which are opposite to the muscarinic symptoms caused by organophosphorus poisoning.

questions.question: A patient with Pink color skin & mucosa, a bitter almond smell from breath, and frothy discharge. The cause of death is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - HCN poisoning Cyanide poisoning (HCN) causes pink skin and mucosa, bitter almond odor from the breath, and frothy discharge, which are key diagnostic clues. It is caused by the exposure to hydrogen cyanide (HCN) or cyanide salts. Cyanide interferes with cellular respiration by inhibiting cytochrome c oxidase , an enzyme in the mitochondria, leading to histotoxic anoxia (cells cannot use oxygen, even when it is available in the bloodstream). Cyanide poisoning Physical Appearance Gaseous state- Hydrogen cyanide (HCN) Liquid form- Hydrocyanic acid or Prussic acid Solid state- salt forms Sources of poisoning Electroplating , photographic processes, rubber, and plastic manufacturing industries Insecticide and rodenticide Drug toxicity: Sodium nitroprusside Military chemical warfare agents Burning of plastic furniture, silk, or wool Cigarette smoking Bitter almonds, peach, apricot, plum, apple, pear, cassava Mode of Action Rapid absorption across both skin and mucous membrane Cyanide salts combine with hydrochloric acid in the stomach to form HCN that is absorbed Inhibition of cytochrome oxidase causes histotoxic anoxia Neurotoxicity Clinical Features Inhalation: Dizziness, vertigo, and constriction of the throat Ingestion: Nausea, headache, loss of muscular power, hypotension, cardiovascular failure, and convulsion Skin: Brick-red color of skin and mucous membranes Anion gap metabolic acidosis and lactic acidosis Diagnosis Lee-Jones test Serum cyanide level Treatment Severe acidosis (pH < 7.1): Administer sodium bicarbonate Antidotal therapy (Eli Lilly cyanide kit approach) First step: Inhalation of Amyl nitrite Second step: Sodium nitrite (3% solution) IV Third step: Sodium thiosulfate (25% solution) IV Other Antidotes 4-dimethylaminophenol (4-DMAP) Hydroxocobalamin (Vitamin B12): Combines with cyanide to form cyanocobalamin, which is excreted in the urine Hyperbaric oxygen Note: Methylene blue is NOT an antidote for cyanide and must NOT be used Autopsy Findings Bitter almond’s odour Brick-red color of skin and mucous membranes Cyanosis of extremities Hemorrhagic gastritis Disseminated petechiae in brain, meninges, pleura, lungs, and pericardium Pulmonary and cerebral edema Note: Mechanism of action of nitrites: It converts hemoglobin to methemoglobinemia which causes the detachment of cyanide from the heme group of cytochrome oxidase. Mechanism of action of sodium thiosulfate: Forms non-toxic thiocyanate which is excreted in the urine. H2S poisoning (Option A) : Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) poisoning typically presents with rotten egg smell from the breath, not the bitter almond smell seen in cyanide poisoning. Symptoms include headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and in severe cases, respiratory failure. The skin typically does not have the pink color seen in cyanide poisoning. CO poisoning (Option B) : Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning leads to a cherry-red skin color , not pink as seen in cyanide poisoning. The breath does not have a bitter almond smell, and the classic symptoms are headache, dizziness, confusion, and weakness, not frothy discharge. OPC poisoning (Option D) : Organophosphate (OP) poisoning typically presents with symptoms such as muscarinic effects (e.g., excessive salivation, lacrimation, urination, diarrhea, gastrointestinal distress) and nicotinic effects (muscle weakness, paralysis). The skin does not have a characteristic pink color, and there is no bitter almond odor from the breath. Frothy discharge is not a typical symptom of OPC poisoning.

questions.question: Which poisoning is caused by a bullet retained inside the body?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Lead Lead is a toxic substance that can be released from retained lead bullets , especially if the bullet is lodged in the body for a prolonged period. Lead gradually leaches into the bloodstream and can cause neurological issues (e.g., confusion, memory problems, and in extreme cases, encephalopathy), kidney damage , gastrointestinal symptoms , and anemia . Causes of Chronic Lead Poisoning: Ingestion or Inhalation of lead-containing dust.: Most common source Lead Paint Dust: Major source for children, especially those under 3 years old. Children are at greater risk due to pica (eating non-nutritive materials). Inhalation by Occupational Exposure: Workers in industries such as white lead manufacturing, lead paint production, plumbing, glass polishing, printing, and glass blowing are at risk. Contaminated Drinking Water: Absorption of lead from water stored in lead cisterns. Lead in Tinned Food Cosmetics and Hair Dyes Petrol and Gasoline: Percutaneous absorption of tetraethyl lead Lead absorption from vermilion (red pigment) used on the scalp. Lead poisoning can result from retained lead bullets or projectiles lodged in the body. Iron (Option A) : Not related to retained bullets. Iron poisoning typically occurs from ingesting large amounts of iron and affects the gastrointestinal system, liver, and kidneys. Phosphorus (Option B) : Occurs from exposure to white phosphorus and causes damage to the liver, but not associated with retained bullets. Nitrocellulose (Option C) : Found in gunpowder, but it does not cause poisoning from retained bullets. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 500, 504

questions.question: Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding the image shown below?

options.A: Only the roots of this plant are poisonous
options.C: Atropine is not specific for aconite poisoning

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Only the roots of this plant are poisonous Explanation: In plants like Aconitum (commonly known as aconite or monkshood ), all parts of the plant, including the roots, leaves, and flowers, are toxic . The plant contains potent alkaloids such as aconitine , which can cause poisoning if ingested. Species Aconitum napellus, Aconitum ferox Synonyms Monk’s hood , mitha zaher, bish, wolf’s bane, women’s bane, devil’s helmet, or blue rocket Source All parts of the plant are poisonous (Option A) Root and root tubers are the most potent (often mistaken for horseradish root) Grown in Mountainous areas of the northern hemisphere. Eg. Sub Himalayan range (Option D ruled out) Active Principles Aconitine, pseudo-aconitine, indaconitine, picraconitine, aconine. Mechanism of Action Affects voltage-sensitive sodium channels, stimulates then paralyzes sensory nerves, secretory nerves, CNS, and myocardium. Symptoms (by system) GIT: Nausea, vomiting, salivation, abdominal pain, diarrhea, burning/tingling of mouth, tongue, throat, followed by numbness. CVS: Hypotension, AV block, bradycardia , chest pain, ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation, slow/feeble pulse. (Option B ruled out) CNS: Vertigo, restlessness, headache, giddiness. MS: Muscle weakness, twitching, spasms. RS: Slow,

questions.question: A patient came to the hospital with muscle weakness, diarrhea, and bradycardia. He was diagnosed with organophosphate poisoning for which atropine was administered. After atropine administration, which of the following changes are not seen?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Bradycardia Explanation: Organophosphate (OP) poisoning causes cholinergic overstimulation by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase , leading to accumulation of acetylcholine at muscarinic and nicotinic receptors. Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist , used to treat the muscarinic symptoms of OP poisoning. OPC poisoning: Symptoms Muscarinic: Lethargy, Salivation, Diarrhea, Lacrimation, Urination, Miosis, Muscle weakness, Bronchorrhea, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Emesis (Mnemonic: DUMBBELLS) Nicotinic: Muscle weakness, Fasciculation, Areflexia, Muscle paralysis CNS: Headache, Tremor, Confusion, Slurred speech, Coma, Convulsion Laboratory Diagnosis RBC/True Cholinesterase (specific) Plasma/Pseudocholinesterase (Most common) Falls rapidly with organophosphorus poisoning Inexpensive, sensitive) Atropine test : If 2 mg of Atropine relieves symptoms, it confirms OP poisoning P-nitro phenol test for confirmation. Management Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing-Circulation) Decontamination Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4 Activated charcoal Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization) Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms removes phosphate group reduces atropine requirement Cause of Death Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP) Option Explanation Seen after atropine? Bradycardia Reversed by atropine (muscarinic blockade) Not seen Muscle weakness Nicotinic effect; not reversed by atropine Seen Diaphoresis Muscarinic effect; reversed by atropine Seen before, improves Nasal discharge Muscarinic effect; reversed by atropine Seen before, improves Muscle weakness (option B): Remains because atropine does not affect nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction. Diaphoresis (option C): Caused by muscarinic stimulation → improves with atropine. Nasal discharge (option D): Muscarinic effect → improves with atropine.

questions.question: What is the cause of death in smoke inhalation ?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Anemic hypoxia Explanation: The primary cause of death in smoke inhalation is anemic hypoxia, which occurs due to the inability of hemoglobin to effectively transport oxygen to tissues. This condition can arise from carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning, a common consequence of smoke inhalation. CO has a much higher affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen, which leads to reduced oxygen delivery to vital organs, ultimately causing systemic hypoxia and potential organ failure. Incorrect Options: Histotoxic hypoxia (Option A) occurs when cells are unable to effectively use oxygen, often due to the presence of toxic substances, such as cyanide. While cyanide can be released during combustion, histotoxic hypoxia is not the primary cause of death in smoke inhalation. The main mechanism of death in smoke inhalation is related to the impaired ability of hemoglobin to carry oxygen, as seen in anemic hypoxia. Ischemic hypoxia (Option B) results from inadequate blood flow to tissues, which can lead to a shortage of oxygen supply. In severe cases of smoke inhalation, respiratory failure could reduce oxygen perfusion to tissues, but this is not the primary cause of death in most cases of smoke inhalation. The main issue is the impaired oxygen binding by hemoglobin due to carbon monoxide (CO), leading to anemic hypoxia. All of the above (Option D): While histotoxic hypoxia and ischemic hypoxia can be involved in some cases of smoke inhalation (especially if toxic gases like cyanide are present), anemic hypoxia is the primary cause of death in smoke inhalation due to the carbon monoxide (CO) binding to hemoglobin. Therefore, "All of the above" is not the correct answer. Reference: Smoke Inhalation Smoke Inhalation Injury: Etiopathogenesis, Diagnosis, and Management - PMC Hypoxia (Hypoxemia): Low Blood Oxygen Signs, Causes, Treatment

questions.question: A little boy was playing in a garden. Suddenly, he collapsed and was rushed to the hospital. His friend who played with him in the garden informed the doctors that he ate one of the fruits in the garden post which he seemed to have developed these symptoms. He also had irritability, restlessness, dry hot skin, and was unable to pass urine and stools. Identify the poison and its appropriate antidote.
questions.explanation: likely due to the ingestion of Datura seeds. Physostigmine 1mg IV (hourly) is used as an antidote for datura poisoning. Datura contains hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine and traces of atropine Mechanism of Action: Initially, it stimulates the higher centers of the brain and then activates the motor centers. Later, it leads to depression of the vital centers in the medulla, resulting in paralysis. Clinical features: Dryness of mouth and throat Dysphagia Difficulty in talking Hoarseness of voice Flushed face Pupil dilatation Photophobia + Diplopia Agitation and restlessness Delirium Urinary retention Dry and hot skin Exfoliation of skin may occur Patients can end up in a coma, or death can occur due to respiratory paralysis. Treatment Gastrointestinal decontamination: Administer activated charcoal to absorb toxins. Use a cathartic if indicated. Antidote: Administer Physostigmine 1-2 mg IV slowl y, repeating as necessary based on symptom response. Symptomatic treatment: Consider Pilocarpine 5 mg subcutaneously for severe anticholinergic effects. Supportive care: Monitor vital signs and address any respiratory or cardiovascular issues. Toxins and Antidotes: Toxicity Antidote Mechanism of action Datura/anticholinergics toxicity Physostigmine Inhibits acetylcholinesterase enzyme Opium Naloxone Opioid receptor antagonist Organophosphates Atropine Pralidoxime Muscarinic antagonist Cholinesterase reactivation Acetaminophen N-acetyl-cysteine Replenishes Glutathione Methanol Fomepizole Inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase Benzodiazepine Flumazenil Inhibits GABA receptors Cyanide Eli Lilly antidote Kit (3-step approach) Amyl nitrate: Oxidises haemoglobin to methemoglobin, which scavenges cyanide. Sodium nitrate: causes cyanide to detach from the heme group of cytochrome oxidase. Amyl nitrate is used as a temporary measure until IV Sodium nitrate can be given. Sodium thiosulphate:It activates an enzyme that converts cyanide to a less toxic agent, thiocyanate. Datura, Pralidoxime (Option A) Pralidoxime, is an antidote used for organophosphate poisoning, not specifically for Datura poisoning. Organophosphates are a different class of toxic compounds that inhibit acetylcholinesterase, but they have different mechanisms of action compared to Datura alkaloids. Yellow oleander, Digoxin and Yellow oleander, Physostigmine (Option C and D) Yellow oleander (Thevetia peruviana) is a plant that contains cardiac glycosides, particularly Thevetin A and Thevetin B. Ingestion of yellow oleander can lead to cardiac toxicity, including arrhythmias, conduction disturbances, and cardiac arrest Digoxin, is a cardiac glycoside commonly used in the treatment of heart failure and certain cardiac arrhythmias. It has a narrow therapeutic index, and overdose or toxicity can result in various cardiac manifestations, including arrhythmias.

questions.question: A young teenage boy with a history of drug abuse had been instilled with a shot of intravenous cocaine at a party. He is rushed to the emergency room by his friends. Some of the symptoms were diaphoresis, headache, and acute coronary spasm. Which of the following symptoms noted would go against the likely diagnosis of cocaine poisoning?
questions.explanation: (excessive sweating), headache, acute coronary spasm leading to myocardial ischemia (reduced blood flow to the heart), and agitation. Cocaine use usually leads to tachycardia (rapid heart rate) as one of its effects on the cardiovascular system. Cocaine Origin Leaves of Erythroxylum coca Local names Coke, snow, Cadillac, White lady Physical properties Colourless, odourless, crystalline, bitter taste Mechanism of action It is a potent central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that produces initial euphoria and increased energy, followed by depression as its effects wear off. It enhances alertness and activity while stimulating the autonomic nervous system, leading to increased heart rate and elevated blood pressure. Route of administration Snorting, Smoking, IV injection Signs of abuse Septal perforation Crack hands (multiple blackened, hyperkeratotic lesions on the fingers and palms). Black staining of tongue and teeth Effects Stages 1. Stage of excitement Feeling of well-being Loss of depression and fatigue Excited and restless (Option D) Tingling sensation in hands and feet Increased heart rate (Option B) Increase in temperature (Option C) Rapid and deep respiration 2. Stage of depression Profuse perspiration Convulsion Reduced respiratory rate Complications Cardiac arrhythmia Cardiac failure Cardiovascular collapse Cerebrovascular accident Aortic dissection Myocardial infarction (Option A) Skin necrosis Intracerebral hemorrhage Formication (Cocaine Bugs) Management of fatal dose Maintain airway, breathing and circulation If ingested: Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate If snorted: Wash the nasal mucous membrane with water If injected: Ligature over the injection site Amyl nitrite via inhalation route Thiamine 100 mg IV injection Naloxone hydrochloride 2mg IV injection Symptomatic management for convulsions using barbiturates

questions.question: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image?
questions.explanation: Semecarpus Anacardium Semecarpus Anacardium: It is used to create artificial bruises (malingering) but is not commonly used for Arrow and cattle poisoning. Abrus precatorius is used as an arrow poison and ideal cattle poison. Semecarpus Anacardium: Commonly known as the marking nut or bhilawanol (washermen use its juice to inscribe identification numbers on clothes). Seeds: Black, cone/heart-shaped with a rough projection at the base. They have a thick pericarp that contains an acrid, brownish, oily juice that turns black upon exposure to air. Active principles: Semecarpol and Bhilawanol Signs and Symptoms: Skin exposure: Applying the juice can cause irritation, itching, and painful blisters filled with acrid serum. Eczematous eruptions resembling bruises may also occur, potentially evolving into ulcers with sloughing. Constitutional symptoms include fever and painful micturition, often accompanied by brown-colored urine. Oral ingestion: A large dose can cause blisters in the mouth and throat, severe gastrointestinal irritation, dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, cyanosis, loss of reflexes,

questions.question: Identify the seeds shown in the image below:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Nigella sativa Explanation: Nigella sativa (black seed) is a medicinal plant from the Ranunculaceae family, widely used in traditional medicines like Unani , Ayurveda , and Tibb-e-Nabwi . These are small, black, angular seeds commonly known as black cumin or kalonji, used in cooking and traditional medicine. Therapeutic Uses : It has various health benefits, including anti-hypertensive, anti-diabetic, anti-cancer, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and hepatoprotective properties. Key Component : The active compound, thymoquinone , in the oil and seeds, is responsible for most of its therapeutic effects. Common Uses : It is used to treat conditions like bronchitis, asthma, diarrhea, rheumatism, and skin disorders, and also as a digestive aid, appetite stimulant, and immune booster. Cultural Significance : Considered a "miracle herb," it is highly regarded in Islamic medicine, where it is believed to cure all diseases except death. Incorrect Options: Tropicana canna (Option A): The seeds are large, spherical, and hard, typically used as beads or ornaments. They do not resemble the smaller, black, and shiny seeds of Nigella sativa. Datura seeds (Option C): Datura seeds are flat, kidney-shaped, and brownish-yellow, distinct from the black seeds of Nigella sativa. Opium seeds (Option D): Also known as poppy seeds, they are small, round, and greyish-blue, distinctly different in color and texture from Nigella sativa seeds.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the management of snakebite in India?

options.A: Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite
options.B: Neostigmine and ventilatory support are used in treatment along with ASV
options.C: ASV is the mainstay of treatment
options.D: Current ASV in India is not effective against humped pit viper

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite neostigmine may assist in reversing neurotoxic paralysis caused by snake venom (e.g., postsynaptic blockade in some bites), its role is secondary to antivenom therapy and ventilatory support . Atropine is given to counteract bradycardia caused by neostigmine but is not specific to krait bites. Treatment of snake bite: First Aid: ‘ CARRY NO RIGHT ’ CARRY Do not allow the victim to walk on their own, must be carried (in any form) to the hospital as soon as possible. NO No Suction No Cautery No Ligature No Tourniquet RIGHT R: Reassure the patient I: Immobilize the limb: by application of crepe bandages (Sutherland wraps) GH: Get to the Hospital immediately T: Tell history/symptoms Pressure bandage Used for immobilization of the limb by application of crepe bandage - known as Sutherland wraps . Contraindicated in viper bites. Ideal pressure: 50-70 mm Hg. ASV Mainstay of treatment. Used only when signs of systemic poisoning are present Polyvalent anti snake venom (PAV) used in India can neutralize (i) Cobra (ii) Krait (iii) Russel viper (iv) Saw-scaled viper bites. Dose: 1-2 ml/kg (!0 vials) irrespective of sex/age. Each vial: neutralizes 6-8 mg of snake venom Test dose is not required/advised to be given before initiating ASV. Ideally to be given within 4 hours of snake bite. To be given until clinical improvement (in cobra bites)/ Clotting time becomes normal (in viper bites). Adjuvant treatment Neostigmine 1.5mg: for neuroparalytic symptoms (cobra bite) . Atropine 0.5mg: To antagonize muscarinic actions of Ach. Surgical debridement and FFP may be required in Viper bites. Incorrect Options: Neostigmine and ventilatory support are used in treatment along with ASV (Option B): Neostigmine may help reverse neurotoxic effects (especially postsynaptic) when combined with ventilatory support. Anti-snake venom (ASV) remains the primary treatment. ASV is the mainstay of treatment (Option C): Polyvalent ASV is the mainstay for treating bites from the "big four" venomous snakes in India (cobra, krait, Russell's viper, and saw-scaled viper). Current ASV in India is not effective against humped pit viper (Option D): The polyvalent ASV available in India is ineffective against humped pit viper venom because it does not include antibodies specific to this species. Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy pages- 424-430. Parikh's Textbook of Medical Jurisprudence, Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 8th edition, page 603

questions.question: Match the following poisons with their probable mechanism of action: A. Zinc chloride 1. Abortifacient B. Chloral hydrate 2. Irritant C. Quinine 3. Corrosive D. Potassium carbonate 4. Stupefying
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3 Explanation: Zinc chloride (A-2): Acts as an irritant due to its caustic effect on tissues. Chloral hydrate (B-4): Causes stupefaction due to its sedative-hypnotic action. Quinine (C-1): Known for its abortifacient property as it can stimulate uterine contractions. Potassium carbonate (D-3): Functions as a corrosive agent due to its strong alkali nature. Reference: Zinc Chloride | ZnCl2 | CID 5727 - PubChem Chloral hydrate - LiverTox - NCBI Bookshelf Toxicities of Herbal Abortifacients - PMC Potassium Carbonate | K2CO3 | CID 11430 - PubChem

questions.question: What is the drug that commonly leads to physical dependence?
questions.explanation: derived from morphine. It is highly addictive and is known to cause physical dependence. When individuals use heroin regularly, their body adapts to the presence of the drug, and they develop a tolerance to its effects. This means that over time, they require higher doses of heroin to achieve the desired effect. If a person becomes physically dependent on heroin and abruptly stops using it or significantly reduces its dosage, they may experience withdrawal symptoms. These symptoms can be severe and include cravings, restlessness, muscle and bone pain, insomnia, gastrointestinal distress, and flu-like symptoms. Heroin: Drug Class Opioid (Narcotic) Origin Derived from morphine, which is extracted from the opium poppy plant. Forms Powder (white or brown), black tar (sticky resin) Route of Administration Injected, smoked, snorted, orally ingested Effects Euphoria Pain relief Relaxation Drowsiness Slowed breathing Sedation Symptoms Drowsiness Nausea Vomiting Slow or shallow breathing Unconsciousness Overdose Constipation Dizziness Long-Term Risks Addiction Liver and kidney damage Collapsed veins (if injected) Lung complications Brain damage Overdose Withdrawal Symptoms Anxiety Sweating Muscle pain Nausea Vomiting Diarrhea Insomnia Cravings Overdose Symptoms Slow or difficult breathing Blue lips or nails Unconsciousness Pinpoint pupils Death Treatment Methadone or buprenorphine replacement therapy Counseling and rehabilitation. Ketamine (Option A) is a dissociative anesthetic that produces hallucinogenic effects. While it can lead to psychological dependence, it is not typically associated with significant physical dependence. LSD (Option C) is a hallucinogenic drug that does not typically produce physical dependence. However, it can lead to psychological dependence or addiction in some individuals. Phencyclidine (Option D) is a dissociative drug that can cause hallucinations, distorted perceptions, and other psychological effects. It is not commonly associated with physical dependence, but it can lead to psychological dependence in some cases. Reference: Knight's Forensic Pathology 4th Edition.2016 Pg no.: 614-616.

questions.question: Which of the following poisons can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body?
questions.explanation: remains of the body. It has the ability to accumulate in bones over time, making it detectable even after the decomposition of soft tissues. Arsenic is a heavy metal, it replaces phosphorus and gets absorbed into the bones, where it may remain for years. Postmortem findings of Arsenic Poisoning External findings Internal findings Emaciation Raindrop pigmentation Keratosis Alopecia White streaks on nails (Aldrich Mees’ lines) Jaundice and muscle wasting, Nasal septum ulceration. Sunken eyeballs Cyanosed and shrunken body. Rigor mortis (sets in late and persists for a prolonged duration) Reddening of stomach mucosa (red velvet or strawberry) due to gastrointestinal congestion. Flea-bitten appearance of the stomach (due to focal haemorrhages). The inflammation and presence of “rice water” contents in the intestines. Subendocardial haemorrhages in the heart. Fatty degeneration of the heart, liver, and kidneys. Along with routine viscera and body fluids, the items preserved for chemical analysis are: A piece of long bone (preferably femur) A bunch of pulled scalp hair A wedge of muscle A small portion of skin (from the back of the trunk) Carbon monoxide (Option B) is a gas that is produced during the incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials. It is unlikely to be found in skeletonized remains since it is a volatile gas that dissipates quickly and does not accumulate in the body or bones. Hydrogen sulphide (Option C) is a toxic gas that has a strong odor of rotten eggs. Similar to carbon monoxide, it is unlikely to be found in skeletonized remains as it is a volatile gas that dissipates rapidly and does not accumulate in the body or bones. Phosphorus (Option D) is a chemical element that can be toxic in certain forms, such as white phosphorus. However, it is not typically found in skeletonized remains as it is highly reactive and tends to undergo chemical reactions or degradation over time.

questions.question: A patient was brought to the casualty with greenish color skin and a rotten egg odour. The most probable poisoning could be.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hydrogen sulfide Explanation: Hydrogen sulfide (H I S) is a highly toxic gas with a characteristic rotten egg odor. It affects cellular respiration by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase, similar to cyanide poisoning but with distinct features. Key Features of Hydrogen Sulfide Poisoning: Skin "font-size: 11pt; font-variant:normal; white-space:pre-wrap" > Greenish discoloration (due to sulfhemoglobin formation) Odor : Rotten egg smell (from hydrogen sulfide gas) Respiratory : Severe pulmonary irritation, dyspnea, and respiratory failure CNS : Headache, dizziness, seizures, coma Cardiac : Bradycardia, hypotension, sudden collapse Rapid onset of toxicity due to cellular hypoxia Mechanism : Inhibits cytochrome c oxidase in the electron transport chain → cellular hypoxia → metabolic acidosis. Incorrect Options: Carbon monoxide (Option A): Cherry red skin, no odor. Nitrite (Option B): Chocolate brown blood (methemoglobinemia). Cyanide (Option C): Bitter almond odor, pink skin, rapid onset of toxicity. Reference: H2S

questions.question: Cause of Opisthotonus is?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Strychnine Explanation: Alkaloid from seeds of strychnos nux-vomica causes opisthotonus. Opisthotonus is a severe form of muscle spasm where the body is arched backward due to involuntary contractions of the back muscles, especially the paraspinal muscles. Cause: Strychnine poisoning is the classic cause. It acts as a glycine antagonist in the spinal cord, leading to: Loss of inhibitory control in motor neurons. Uncontrolled muscle contractions and spasms. Cocaine (Option A): Causes CNS stimulation, tremors, seizures, not opisthotonus. Codeine (Option B): Opioid, causes CNS depression, respiratory depression, not muscle spasms. Curare (Option D): A muscle relaxant causing flaccid paralysis, not spasms. Reference: Strychnine

questions.question: Identify the active toxin extracted from the poisonous plant in the image below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1-Hyoscyamine Explanation: The above image shows Atropa Belladonna, also called the deadly nightshade. It produces an active poisonous component called hyoscyamine. The toxin may also be found in datura Stramonium (Jimson weed) Hyoscyamine is an isomer of Atropine and has Anticholinergic and Antimuscarinic activity. It is used as an antiemetic, anti-secretory and antispasmodic agent in the treatment of naused, motion sickness, allergic rhinitis etc. Side effects include dryness of the mouth and eyes, tachycardia, palpitations, decreased sweating, and can also produce anxiety and restlessness. Calotropis Gigantea (Option A): It is a purple colored flower which has an active poisonous principle called Calotropin, Calotoxin. Digitalis (Option B): Also called purple foxglove where the poison acts by inhibiting Na-K ATPase channel. Ricin (Option C): Produced by castor plant where it inhibits RNA polymerase and protein synthesis.

questions.question: In which poisoning is cherry red hypostasis seen on post-mortem examination?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - CO Poisoning Carbon monoxide poisoning causes cherry red discoloration of the skin, mucus membranes, conjunctiva, nail beds, areas of hypostasis, blood tissues and internal organs. This coloration changes to dark green and then to brown as decomposition starts to occur. Post-mortem changes associated with Carbon monoxide poisoning are: Cherry-pink lividity : One of the classic signs of carbon monoxide poisoning is the development of cherry-pink lividity on the skin. This occurs due to the formation of carboxyhemoglobin, a stable complex formed when carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin, resulting in a bright pink or cherry-red coloration of the skin. Discoloration of internal organs: Carbon monoxide poisoning can cause discoloration of internal organs. The organs may appear bright red due to the presence of carboxyhemoglobin. Pulmonary congestion and edema: Carbon monoxide can lead to congestion and fluid accumulation in the lungs, resulting in pulmonary congestion and edema. This can be observed during postmortem examination as fluid-filled lungs with frothy fluid. Macroscopic changes in the brain: Carbon monoxide poisoning can cause macroscopic changes in the brain. The brain may appear swollen and congested, and the white matter can show pink discoloration. Hydrogen Sulphide (Option B): poisoning causes a rotten egg smell in the victim. The general signs of asphyxia are present along with signs of changing of the blood and viscera colour to greenish-purple and not cherry-red. Yellow Phosphorus (Option C): is a potent hepatotoxin. Post-mortem findings include garlicky odour along with icterus of the body due to liver failure as a part of multiple organ failure which causes the death of the victim. Hydrogen cyanide (Option D): is an extremely lethal poison. Post-mortem findings of hydrogen cyanide poisoning include glistening and prominent dilated pupils, frothy mouth, brick-red blood and cheeks due to impaired oxygenation of the tissues. The internal organs may be oedematous due to congestion. Reference: CO

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of antidotes and toxicities is correctly matched? Arsenic - Desferrioxamine

options.A: Organophosphorus - Physostigmine B) Atropine - L-carnitine C) Benzodiazepine - Flumazenil D)

questions.explanation: used to reverse benzodiazepine-induced sedation or overdose. Antidotes and their mechanisms Poisoning Type Antidote Mechanism Arsenic (Option D ruled out) BAL (Dimercaprol) IM, chelates arsenic for excretion. Succimer (DMSA) Oral chelation. DMPS IV, transitioned to oral chelation. Copper Potassium Ferrocyanide Forms insoluble copper complexes, reducing absorption. Penicillamine Chelates copper. Cyanide Sodium Nitrite Forms methemoglobin to bind cyanide. Sodium Thiosulfate Converts cyanide to thiocyanate for renal excretion. Hydroxocobalamin Binds cyanide, forming cyanocobalamin. Dicobalt Edetate, Methylene Blue Alternative antidotes. Ethylene Glycol Ethanol/Fomepizole Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase to prevent toxic metabolites. Iron Desferrioxamine Chelates iron for excretion. Magnesium Hydroxide/Sodium Bicarbonate Note: BAL should not be used in iron, cadmium, or selenium poisoning due to formation of toxic complexes. Precipitate iron, reducing absorption. Lead Sodium/Magnesium Sulfate Forms insoluble lead sulfate. Calcium Chloride/Gluconate Promotes bone deposition of lead. CaNa2EDTA + BAL Chelation therapy for lead elimination. Mercury Sodium Formaldehyde Sulfoxylate Reduces toxic mercury ions. BAL (Dimercaprol) Traditional chelator; oral agents preferred. Methanol Ethanol/Fomepizole Compete for alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing toxic metabolites. Opium Naloxone Blocks opioid receptors, reversing opioid effects. Organophosphate (Option A ruled out) Atropine Blocks muscarinic receptors to manage cholinergic symptoms. Pralidoxime (2-PAM) (Option B ruled out) Reactivates acetylcholinesterase. Phenol Magnesium Sulfate Absorbs phenol in the stomach. Phosphorus Potassium Permanganate Oxidizes phosphorus into harmless phosphates. Strychnine Barbiturates Depress CNS, preventing seizures. Thallium Prussian Blue Binds thallium in the intestine, preventing absorption. Atropine - L-carnitine (Option B): Atropine poisoning is treated with physostigmine, a cholinesterase inhibitor that crosses the blood-brain barrier. L-carnitine has no role in atropine toxicity. Reference: Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 487, 491, 496, 500, 508, 509, 515, 539, 555, 574, 584, 599, 612

questions.question: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry dilated pupil, dry skin , slurring of speech , altered sensorium. The poisoning is?
questions.explanation: symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity, which include dry skin, dilated pupils (mydriasis), slurred speech, and altered sensorium. This is consistent with the clinical presentation described. Incorrect Options Option A - Morphine: Morphine is an opioid and typically causes miosis (constricted pupils), not mydriasis. It can lead to respiratory depression and altered sensorium, but the dry skin and dilated pupils are not characteristic of morphine poisoning. Option B - Cannabis: Cannabis can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech but is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Cannabis effects are typically less severe and do not match the full clinical picture described. Option D - Alcohol: Alcohol can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech, but it is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Alcohol typically causes miosis and does not have the anticholinergic effects seen with Datura.

questions.question: Aldrich mees lines and raindrop pigmentation in hand is seen in which poisoning?
questions.explanation: pigmentation (brownish discoloration) on the hands are characteristic signs of arsenic poisoning. Arsenic is known to cause these distinctive dermatological and nail changes. Arsenic interferes with the keratinization process in the nails, leading to the formation of Mees lines, and can cause pigmentary changes in the skin. Incorrect Options: Option B - Thallium: Thallium poisoning can cause symptoms like hair loss, peripheral neuropathy, and gastrointestinal issues, but it is not typically associated with Aldrich-Mees lines or raindrop pigmentation. Thallium poisoning does have its own set of diagnostic signs but these specific ones are not characteristic. Option C - Cadmium: Cadmium poisoning is associated with kidney damage and bone disease, not with Aldrich-Mees lines or raindrop pigmentation. Cadmium does not produce the same dermatological findings as arsenic. Option D - Lead: Lead poisoning is associated with basophilic stippling of red blood cells, but it does not typically present with Aldrich-Mees lines or raindrop pigmentation. Lead affects different body systems and has different clinical manifestations.

questions.question: Acute liver failure is a clinical feature of which of the following?
questions.explanation: failure. It is a wild mushroom known as the death cap mushroom. Amanita poisoning presents with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, enlarged and tender liver, jaundice, oliguria , mental confusion, convulsions and coma Early mushroom poisoning Late mushroom poisoning Hallucinogenic mushroom poisoning Species Inocybe Amanita phalloides Amanita muscaria Toxin Muscarine Amatoxin (Option A) Muscimol Symptoms Cholinergic symptoms (DUMBBELLS) Hepatotoxicity Hallucinations, seizures Treatment Atropine Thioctic acid Silibinin (hepatoprotective) Supportive treatment ATROPINE CONTRAINDICATED OP poisoning (Option A) presents with pinpoint pupils and diaphoresis, liver failure is not seen Belladonna poisoning (Option C) presents with tachycardia, hallucinations not liver failure Morphine poisoning (Option D) presents with respiratory depression and pinpoint pupils, liver failure is not seen Reference: Mushroom Poisoning - an overview | ScienceDirect Topics . Mushroom Poisoning - PubMed . The Deceptive Mushroom: Accidental Amanita muscaria Poisoning - PMC Diagnosis and Treatment of Amanita Phalloides-Type Mushroom Poisoning: Use of Thioctic Acid - PMC

questions.question: A chronic alcoholic came with complaints of agitation, global confusion, disorientation, hallucination, fever, hypertension, diaphoresis, and autonomic hyperactivity after cessation of alcohol for 48 hours. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: withdrawal that typically occurs 48 to 96 hours after the last drink . It is characterized by: Confusion and disorientation Hallucinations (often visual) Autonomic hyperactivity Coarse tremors Delirium Tremens (DT) Wernicke's Encephalopathy (WE) (Option B) Korsakoff's Syndrome (KS) (Option C) Cause Acute alcohol withdrawal. Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often due to chronic alcoholism. Often a result of chronic alcoholism and thiamine deficiency. Onset 48-72 hours after the last drink. Acute onset, typically develops over 1-2 days . Chronic, long-term condition . Symptoms Severe agitation Tremors Hallucinations Confusion Seizures Autonomic instability. G - Global confusion O - Ophthalmoplegia A - Ataxia P - Polyneuropathy Anterograde and retrograde amnesia (Intact long term memory) Confabulation Memory impairment. Cognitive Function Impaired consciousness, confusion, disorientation. Disorientation, confusion, and memory problems. Severe memory impairment, with intact long-term memory. Motor Symptoms Tremors Hyperreflexia Muscle rigidity. Ataxia (lack of coordination), abnormal gait. Motor function may remain mostly intact. Treatment Thiamine Benzodiazepines Fluids Electrolytes Thiamine supplementation (IM/IV) Fluids Electrolyte correction. Thiamine supplementation Psychological support Rehabilitation therapy. Magnan Phenomena (Option D) refer to tactile hallucinations, such as the sensation of insects crawling on or under the skin, associated with cocaine use rather than alcohol withdrawal Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, pages 547-549 Delirium Tremens Acamprosate for treatment of alcohol dependence

questions.question: A patient was admitted with complaints of tachycardia and arrhythmias. On examination, multiple scratch marks were observed on the body. The probable drug of abuse in this patient is:
questions.explanation: stimulant known for causing tachycardia and arrhythmias, which are common symptoms associated with its abuse. Magnan's Syndrome: Aso known as "Cocaine Bugs," occurs in individuals who use cocaine. It is a type of tactile hallucination where the person experiences the sensation of grains of sand or small insects crawling under the skin, causing itching (formication). Formication is derived from the Latin word formica , meaning "ant," and refers to the feeling that tiny insects are moving across the skin. Causes: Diabetic neuropathy Menopause Skin cancer Herpes zoster Physical or psychological side effect of substance abuse, including cocaine, amphetamines, and alcohol withdrawal (along with delirium tremens). Options B, C, and D are not associated with Magnan syndrome Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 571

questions.question: Which of the following is used for the treatment of Datura poisoning?
questions.explanation: poisoning because it is a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor.. Datura contains hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine and traces of atropine Mechanism of Action: Initially, it stimulates the higher centers of the brain and then activates the motor centers. Later, it leads to depression of the vital centers in the medulla, resulting in paralysis. Clinical features: Dryness of mouth and throat Dysphagia Difficulty in talking Hoarseness of voice Flushed face Pupil dilatation Photophobia + Diplopia Agitation and restlessness Delirium Urinary retention Dry and hot skin Exfoliation of skin may occur Patients can end up in a coma, or death can occur due to respiratory paralysis. Treatment Gastrointestinal decontamination: Administer activated charcoal to absorb toxins. Use a cathartic if indicated. Antidote: Administer Physostigmine 1-2 mg IV slowly , repeating as necessary based on symptom response. Symptomatic treatment: Consider Pilocarpine 5 mg subcutaneously for severe anticholinergic effects. Supportive care: Monitor vital signs and address any respiratory or cardiovascular issues. Toxins and Antidotes: Toxicity Antidote Mechanism of action Datura/anticholinergics toxicity Physostigmine (Option A) Inhibits acetylcholinesterase enzyme Opium Naloxone Opioid receptor antagonist Organophosphates Atropine (Option B) Pralidoxime Muscarinic antagonist Cholinesterase reactivation Acetaminophen N-acetyl-cysteine Replenishes Glutathione Methanol Fomepizole Inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase Benzodiazepine Flumazenil Inhibits GABA receptors Cyanide Eli Lilly antidote Kit (3-step approach) 1. Amyl nitrate: Oxidises haemoglobin to methemoglobin, which scavenges cyanide. 2. Sodium nitrate (Option C) : causes cyanide to detach from the heme group of cytochrome oxidase. Amyl nitrate is used as a temporary measure until IV Sodium nitrate can be given. 3. Sodium thiosulphate:It activates an enzyme that converts cyanide to a less toxic agent, thiocyanate. Neostigmine (Option D) does not cross blood brain barrier

questions.question: In cases of alcohol abuse, in what substance is the blood typically preserved during an autopsy?
questions.explanation: preservative for blood is sodium fluoride. Various methods of preserving viscera: Saturated salt solution Formalin fixation Freezing Alcohol preservation Formaldehyde solution Formalin-alcohol solution Frozen section Liquid nitrogen Specimens for Analysis Specimen Importance Blood Primary specimen; collect from femoral, iliac, or axillary veins to avoid contamination. Preservative: Lithium heparin or EDTA tube, fluoride/oxalate, if alcohol is suspected Urine Useful for detecting parent compounds and metabolites of poisons. Preservative: No preservative, sodium fluoride is added, if alcohol is Suspected (Option A) Gastric Contents Helps identify ingested poisons and their concentrations through vomitus and stomach contents analysis. Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison. (Option D) Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid (Option C) . Liver Analyzes metabolism and concentration of drugs; critical when blood/urine concentrations are low. Bile can detect specific substances like chlorpromazine and morphine. Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison. Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid. Hair and Nails Detects heavy metal poisoning; metals accumulate in keratin. Neutron activation analysis identifies specific metals and exposure patterns. Scene Residues Provides clues about the poison through materials found at the scene, such as tablets or empty containers. Formalin (Option B) is commonly used for general tissue preservation and fixation in anatomical pathology, but it is not specifically preferred for toxicology autopsy. It may affect the results of toxicological analyses. Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, page 114.

questions.question: Which of the following substances are antidotes for cyanide poisoning? Amyl nitrate Sodium nitrate Sodium thiosulphate Benzyl thiocyanate
questions.explanation: nitrate, Sodium nitrate, and Sodium thiosulphate. This is called the Lily cyanide antidote kit Incorrect Options: Option B, C, and D: These are incorrect options.

questions.question: A patient presents with paraesthesia, tetany, muscle twitching, and muscle cramps, along with urinary crystals as shown in the image. These symptoms are typical of poisoning with what substance?
questions.explanation: Signs and symptoms Fulminant poisoning- Burning, sour or bitter taste in the mouth with a sense of constriction around the throat and burning pain from the mouth to stomach, radiating all over the abdomen. Nausea and eructation are immediately followed by vomiting which contains altered blood, mucus and Acute poisoning- Tingling and numbness of fingers and limbs, weakness, paresthesia, carpopedal spasm*, hyperirritability of peripheral nerves (Chvostek/Weiss sign), tetany, convulsions, coma and death. Delayed poisoning- Characterized by nephritis—uremia, scanty urine, hematuria, albuminuria, oxaluria (envelope-shaped calcium oxalate crystals in the urine are seen under microscope). Incorrect Options: Option A - Cystine: Cystine stones are hexagonal or benzene shaped. Option B - Xanthine: Xanthine stones are very uncommon in urine. Option C - Ammonium urate: Uric acid crystals are rosette shaped.

questions.question: A 40-year-old female consumed a white-colored rodenticide powder and presents with a potassium level of 2.5 mEq/L. On examination, she has an irregular pulse and muscle paralysis. ECG shows multiple ventricular ectopics. What is the suspected poison?
questions.explanation: classical features of areflexia and paralysis. Other symptoms include- Tingling sensation, tremors, cramps, stiffness of the muscles, paralysis of the tongue and larynx, myoclonus, myalgia, flaccid quadriplegia, hypertension, arrhythmia, ectopic beats, ventricular fibrillation, irregular pulse, shock, cardiac arrest, pulmonary edema, mydriasis, vertigo, headache, confusion, convulsions. Postmortem findings: Non-specific. Submucosal hemorrhages may be seen in the GIT. Incorrect Options : Option A - Aluminum phosphide: Aluminum phosphide presents with hypotension, arrhythmias, acute CHF, shock, dyspnea, cyanosis, Oliguria, renal failure. altered mental state, restlessness, convulsions, acute hypoxic encephalopathy, coma. muscle wasting, tenderness, bleeding diathesis. Option B - Zinc phosphide: Zinc phosphide presents with dyspnea, lethargy, hypotension, cardiac arrhythmias, pulmonary edema, metabolic acidosis, convulsions, circulatory collapse, coma and death Option C - Warfarin toxicity: Warfarin toxicity, the patient presents with abnormal bleeding, dark urine, dark stools.

questions.question: A farmer presents with a painful snakebite wound on his right foot. There are two fang marks with swelling and bleeding at the bite site. What is the first step in management?

options.B: Sling or splint leading to immobilization
options.D: See the snake brought by a relative

questions.explanation: snake bite involves the “RIGHT strategy.” R: Reassure I: Immobilize G H: Go to the Hospital T: Tell the appropriate history and symptoms to the attending doctor. or coagulopathy, the recommended antivenom dose is 150-200 ml. Management of Snakebite Management Details Indications/Notes First Aid Do not allow the victim to walk (Carry) Avoid tourniquets, except in specific cases(No) Reassure patient Immobilize bitten limb (Option B) Transport to the hospital quickly Tell the doctor about any systemic symptoms Tourniquets only for severe elapid/sea snake bites with >0.5h but <2-3h transport time Evaluation Check for signs of envenomation Monitor vital signs Perform 20-minute whole blood clotting time Check coagulation profile, CPK, renal function Incoagulable blood indicates systemic envenomation by Viperidae Antivenom Therapy Mild: 50 ml Moderate: 50-100 ml Severe: 150-200 ml Effective against the 4 most important venomous snakes in India, namely, Cobra, Common Krait, Russell's viper and saw-scaled viper. Indications: Haemostatic abnormalities Neurotoxicity Cardiovascular dysfunction Impaired consciousness Rhabdomyolysis Extensive local swelling Antivenom Administration (Option A) Dilute in 5 ml/kg body weight of isotonic saline/5% Dextrose Infuse over 1-2 hours Monitor for hypersensitivity reactions Repeat if severe signs persist after 1-2 hours or if coagulability is not restored within 6 hours Supportive Care Tetanus prophylaxis Antibiotics (if severe local reaction) Manage respiratory paralysis Fresh frozen plasma/cryoprecipitates for severe bleeding Avoid heparin, corticosteroids, and EDTA. Venom suction (Option C) is to be avoided in case of a snake bite. See the snake brought by a relative (Option D) This is not necessary as the ASV available is effective against all the common venomous snakes in India. Hence, ASV is administered regardless of the snake that caused the bite. Reference: Pubmed First aid

questions.question: Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following poisonings?
questions.explanation: petroleum products) are highly dangerous if aspirated into the lungs. They can cause severe chemical pneumonitis and aspiration pneumonia, so gastric lavage is contraindicated in hydrocarbon poisoning. Gastric Lavage in Poisoning Management Gastric lavage is a procedure to remove ingested poison by introducing and withdrawing fluids through an orogastric tube. Its effectiveness depends on timing, proper technique, and patient-specific considerations. Timing and Effectiveness Most effective within 1 hour of ingestion (Option A ruled out) Can be beneficial up to 4-6 hours in select cases Beyond 6 hours , poison likely passes into the intestines, reducing lavage efficacy Procedure Steps Step Details Patient Positioning Trendelenburg: Head down to prevent aspiration Left lateral decubitus: Reduces chance of poison entering the duodenum Tube Placement Confirmation Inject air and listen for gastric bubbling sounds Watch for coughing or bubbles (indicates misplacement in trachea) Fluid Administration Fluid is administered and aspirated using a syringe attached to the tube Fluid Selection Tap water for most cases Normal saline for infants Specific solutions (e.g., potassium permanganate) may be used for certain poisons Residual Fluid Leave a small amount of fluid to neutralize remaining poison Contraindications Corrosive Poisoning : Avoid except for carbolic acid (phenol) to prevent perforation Convulsant Poisons : Risk of triggering seizures (e.g., strychnine) Comatose Patients : High aspiration risk Volatile Poisons/Hydrocarbons : May cause aspiration pneumonitis (Option C) Risk of Hemorrhage/Perforation : Avoid if esophageal varices or recent surgery present Additional Contraindications to Emetics Severe heart or lung diseases Advanced pregnancy CNS depression or seizures Complications Complication Details Aspiration Occurs in ~10% of cases. Risk of lung injury Esophageal/Gastric Perforation Can be life-threatening Tube Misplacement Misplaced into trachea, causing complications Bleeding Can occur with improper technique or pathology Alternatives to Gastric Lavage Alternative Description Emetics Induce vomiting in conscious patients Dilution Large water intake to dilute corrosive substances Endoscopic/Surgical Removal Used for toxic foreign bodies or drug packets

questions.question: Unknown substance consumption leading to tachycardia and red-colored halo is seen with?
questions.explanation: indicative of consumption of LSD. LSD - Lysergic acid Diethylamide: Acid blotter or paper stamp or taken as fumes. Obtained from rye fungus (ergot). Increases serotonin level in the brain (only psychological dependence). Associated with the trip (most common) Good trip Visual hallucinations and illusions Bad trip Anxiety Panic attacks Flashback phenomenon is seen (re-experiencing the past experience). Incorrect Options: Cannabis (Option A) (marijuana) use typically does not cause significant tachycardia. While cannabis can induce visual hallucinations in some individuals, they are more commonly associated with LSD and other hallucinogens. Crack/ cocaine (Option B) use is known to cause tachycardia due to its stimulant effects on the central nervous system. Cocaine can sometimes induce tactile hallucinations of bugs crawling on the skin (formication). Heroine (Option D) use is more commonly associated with symptoms such as sedation, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils (miosis).

questions.question: Among the listed options, which substance is not utilized as a chelating agent in cases of heavy metal poisoning?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Oximes Explanation: Oximes, such as pralidoxime, are not chelating agents. They are used as antidotes in organophosphate poisoning by reactivating acetylcholinesterase, which is inhibited by the poison. Deferiprone (Option A): Deferiprone is a chelating agent used to treat iron overload, commonly seen in conditions like thalassemia major. It binds to iron and facilitates its excretion. EDTA (Option B): Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) is a well-known chelating agent used in cases of lead and other heavy metal poisonings. It binds metal ions, aiding in their excretion. Penicillamine (Option C): Penicillamine is an effective chelating agent for metals like copper (used in Wilson's disease) and lead. It binds metals and facilitates their removal from the body. Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by Narayan Reddy and OP Murty, 35th Edition, Page 393-394 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology by Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 479, 491, 496, 500, 506 https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16305472/

questions.question: Match the poisons and their site of action. A. Datura 1. CVS B. Nicotine 2. CNS
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4 Explanation: Datura (A-2): Datura primarily acts on the central nervous system (CNS). Actions Anticholinergic effects: CNS stimulant initially (causing anticholinergic effects such as delirium, hallucinations, and confusion), followed by CNS depression (respiratory center). Vagolytic action: Heart stimulation. Nicotine (B-1): Nicotine affects the cardiovascular system (CVS) by stimulating nicotinic receptors, leading to tachycardia, hypertension, and vasoconstriction. Nitric acid (C-3): Nitric acid primarily affects the skin, causing corrosive injuries, burns, and tissue damage upon contact. Nux vomica (strychnine) (D-4): Strychnine acts on the spinal cord, causing excitation of motor neurons, leading to muscle spasms and convulsions. Clinical Features Opisthotonus - arched body with only the back of head and heels touching the ground: Emprosthotonus- forward curve Pleurothotonus- sideways curve Risus sardonicus- fixed grin:

questions.question: Which of the following is not a symptom associated with chronic cocaine abuse?

options.C: Dilated pupils, rapid pulse and sweating.
options.D: Hallucination of insects crawling on the skin (formication).

questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Dilated pupils, rapid pulse and sweating. Seen in acute cocaine poisoning Mechanism of action of cocaine: Inhibits the synaptic reuptake of Epinephrine, Norepinephrine, Dopamine, Serotonin. All these substances will increase synaptic cleft.This will cause Sympathomimetic Toxidrome Chronic Cocaine Abuse: Cocainism, Cocainomania or Cocainophagia Tolerance for high doses Rush (When excited) and crash (when depressed) Triad of cocaine abuse: Nasal / Palatal perforation Black tongue and teeth Gangrene of periphery (Nose tip, ear lobule) Cocaine bugs is aka Magnan symptom or formication: This is tactile hallucination. It seems like insects, mice or rats are crawling on skin. Treatment: Antidote : Amyl nitrite to control heart rate and BP Supportive and Symptomatic treatment Fatal dose: Around 1g Reference: Cocaine toxicity

questions.question: A 50-year-old factory worker was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting and blurring of vision after he consumed local spirit. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Fomepizole Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase . Alcohol dehydrogenase catalyses the oxidation of ethanol to acetaldehyde. Alcohol dehydrogenase also catalyses the initial steps in the metabolism of ethylene glycol and methanol to their toxic metabolites. Features or symptoms of methanol poisoning: Gastrointestinal Distress: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea are common symptoms associated with methanol poisoning. Neurological Symptoms: Methanol toxicity affects the central nervous system and can lead to symptoms such as headache, dizziness, confusion, disorientation, agitation, and seizures. Visual Impairment: Methanol poisoning can cause visual disturbances, including blurred vision, double vision, or complete loss of vision. This is due to the toxic effect of methanol on the optic nerve. Metabolic Acidosis: Methanol is metabolized in the body to formic acid and formaldehyde, which can lead to metabolic acidosis—a disturbance in the body's acid-base balance.
